title: Can a financial advisor help me become rich? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, but with many caveats. If you know little about investing, you could be making costly mistakes like picking the wrong stocks, picking the wrong funds, or investing in high risk assets like crypto or commodities that blow up. A financial advisor might help you set up a diversified portfolio that will grow in value overtime. The caveats are: Financial advisors do not work for free. They may charge you an asset under management fee like 1% of your asset each year. Considering that stocks generally return 5% real pre-tax and 3% real after-tax, the AUM fee could cost you a third to a fifth of your return each year. The effect of the fee compound over time and could cost you up to HALF of your net worth over time. Not good at all when you are the one taking all the risk while the financial advisor spends only a minute to rebalance your portfolio each year, if that.The portfolio financial advisors tend to recommend are very conservative, often with more bonds that one needs. They do that to avoid losing, because many investors cannot stomach a 50% drop in their portfolio during a bear market. This “conservatism” could prevent you from getting rich, as fixed income assets do not even keep up with inflation after taxes.Financial advisors tend to recommend style funds that have higher expenses. For example, instead of a simple 2-security portfolio of a total stock market fund and a total bond market fund, they may recommend a 10-security portfolio of a large cap value fund, a large cap growth fund, a mid cap value fund, a mid cap growth fund, a small cap value fund, a small cap growth fund, an REIT fund, a TIPs fund, an investment grade corp bond fund, and a junk bond fund. The parts add up to the whole, but cost a lot more individually. Financial advisors do this because they want to add complexity to make you think you need them to manage your portfolio.Worse yet, some financial advisors are non-fiduciaries and may steer you toward high expense actively managed mutual funds, annuities, and life insurance so they earn a fatter commission for themselves. Over time, not only will it not make you rich, but may even send you to the poor house.How to combat this? Education. We live in the information age and can easily teach ourselves basic financial management for free through tons of books on personal finance in the public library and online. Read up.Just invest in a low cost broad stock market index fund. For example, VTI charges only 0.03% expense ratio with no capital distributions and tracks the entire US stock market. 80% of money managers underperform the market. Buying and holding an index fund allows you to capture the entire market return less a very small fee without having to do anything or know anything about investing at all.If you must hire a financial advisor, hire a fee-only fiduciary financial advisor on a hourly basis only (never pay an AUM fee!!!) to help you set up a financial plan. If applicable, check with your company HR to see they already have paid-for financial advisors that you could talk to for free.

A financial advisor might be able to help you better diversify your investments and improve your pick of investments, but they will not likely make you rich. The only person that can make you rich is generally you. Having a good financial sense and saving money helps you become rich.Not living above your own financial means will help you become rich.Not buying the stuff you don’t need helps you become rich.Learning in-demand skills helps you become rich.There are a lot of things that can help you become rich, but a financial advisor is not typically one of them. Financial advisors can provide value to the right person, but the value is most often not in the investment returns they provide. The truth is most advisors and even mutual fund managers themselves do not outperform a market index over 80% of the time in a 15 year period. A financial advisor can bring value with experience on better investment diversification and even advice on better tax-advantaged investments. For most middle-income people without tax problems or much money to invest, it can often be better to just educate yourself and invest conservatively if it is for the long term. Often you will do just as good or better than an advisor once you add in their fees and commissions. There is nothing wrong with using a financial advisor, but they are not generally going to make you wealthy. A good advisor might help you depending on your situation, but a bad advisor might even make you less wealthy. The financial advisor industry is like any other one. There are good professional people in the industry and terrible people that look to only make a profit. The trick is finding the right one. Here is a previous article I wrote Does Everyone Need a Financial Advisor? That goes more into depth on why not everyone needs a financial advisor. If you are going to hire a financial professional. Do it for the right reasons and not to become rich. They won’t make you rich, but they might help with a path to get you there.

Wealth creation is an area financial advisors assist their clients. Creating riches beyond your wildest dreams, probably not. Their role is to provide advice covering all aspects of a person's financial life so building wealth is certainly a key component. An adviser would certainly help you develop a systematic approach to saving, but ‘riches’ would be accomplished over years rather than in weeks or months.

Probably not. You are the prime contributor to your wealth. Without an advisor you could also become wealthy. Just invest your savings in an index fund like SPY and you should be fine. If your advisor is super smart, then there is an outside chance they’d make you a bit richer but on average its a remote chance they will consistently beat the market.

NO ONLY YOU CAN HELP YOURSELF BY: Leading a frugal lifestyle.No more than 50% of your take-home pay for Essential expensesSave 20% of your take-home pay for “Rainy Days” (retirement)Save 10% of your pay building up an emergency fund which should be about 6 months worth of your Essential expensesKeep 10% of your take-home for Discretionary expensesDoing all the above things together will make you rich in about 20–25 years

I suppose so, but he/she can’t force you to save a lot of money and invested sensibly. Those are really the basics. You don’t need a fancy financial advisor – – and the fees they charge – – to become wealthy. Plenty of us have done it on our own, investing sensibly in low-cost, well-diversified equity index mutual funds. You can learn all about it on Vanguard’s website.

Probably not, because they usually won’t advise you to take the big risks that might make you rich but have a more likely outcome of losing. They will, however, help you be comfortable with reasonably safe investments. Look at it more as planning how to never be poor.

Financial advisors do not make people rich , they simply gives you a plan to follow according to your very personal situation and financial position . Money come son the way if you remain determined and keep working like wise. However it is not true that you get 100% success because market condition , political situation of the country and world matters brings changes in the working environment , some time things goes in your favour or some time against you , all it needs to act in the prescribed direction and wait for the result.

They can help on the margin but they cant do it for you. For example. One year they could help you earn 1,100,000 as opposed to 1,000,000 Over time that difference can add up but you still have to do the heavy lifting yourself.
